language_info.description: Complete beginner level focusing on survival Dutch

lessons.title: Lesson 1 — In the park: meeting people

content.text: Welkom bij je eerste les Nederlands! Let's learn how to greet people and start a simple conversation in a Dutch park.

content.title: Subject Pronouns: I & You
content.explanation: Let's start with the basics. 'Ik' means 'I'. 'Jij' or the shorter 'je' means 'you' (informal).

content.title: To be: 'zijn'
content.explanation: To say 'I am', you say 'Ik ben'. To say 'you are', you say 'Jij bent'.

content.title: To be called: 'heten'
content.explanation: For names, you can also use the verb 'heten'. 'Ik heet' means 'I am called'. 'Jij heet' means 'You are called'.

content.text: 'Ik ben...' and 'Ik heet...' are both used for introductions. 'Ik ben...' is a bit more common in casual conversation.

content.title: Word Order: Verb-Second
content.explanation: In simple Dutch sentences, the verb always comes in the second position. For example: 'Ik (1) ben (2) Mark.'

data.tip: The Dutch 'g' is a soft, throaty sound from the back of your throat, similar to the 'ch' in the Scottish word 'loch'.

content.title: First Introduction
content.setting: You see someone friendly sitting on a park bench. You decide to go over and say hello.

user_goal.title: Tell them your name using 'Ik ben...'
user_goal.prompt: Aangenaam! Ik ben Anna. En jij?

extract_info.user_name: Extract the user's name from their message

content.title: Formal 'You': U
content.explanation: Besides 'jij/je', there is a formal way to say 'you': 'u'. You use it with strangers, older people, or in formal settings.

content.title: Verb Forms with 'u'
content.explanation: When using the formal 'u', the verb forms are: 'u bent' (you are) and 'u heet' (you are called).

content.text: When in doubt, using 'u' is always the safer, more polite option. The other person will often suggest switching to 'je'.

content.title: To come: 'komen'
content.explanation: 'Ik kom' means 'I come'. 'Jij komt' means 'You come'. 'U komt' also means 'You come' (formal).

content.title: Wh- Questions
content.explanation: Questions starting with a question word (like 'Waar') follow this order: Question Word - Verb - Subject. For example: 'Waar kom jij...?'

content.title: More Pronouns: He & She
content.explanation: 'Hij' means 'he'. 'Zij' or 'ze' means 'she'. The verb forms are the same as for 'jij': 'hij is', 'zij heet', 'hij komt'.

content.title: Plural Pronouns
content.explanation: 'Wij' or 'we' means 'we'. 'Jullie' means 'you' (plural). 'Zij' or 'ze' means 'they'.

content.title: Plural Verb Forms
content.explanation: For all plural pronouns ('wij', 'jullie', 'zij'), the verb form is the infinitive: 'wij zijn', 'jullie heten', 'zij komen'.

content.title: Yes/No Questions
content.explanation: To form a question that can be answered with yes or no, you put the verb first: Verb - Subject... For example: 'Spreek jij Engels?'

content.text: Time for some small talk! Talking about the weather is always a good start in the Netherlands.

content.title: A Full Conversation
content.setting: You are walking your dog in the park and meet an older gentleman who comments on the weather. Time to practice everything you've learned!

user_goal.title: Agree with him about the weather
Introduce yourself politely
user_goal.prompt: Zeker! Ik ben meneer De Wit. Aangenaam.

extract_info.user_name: Extract the user's name from their message

user_goal.title: Ask him where he is from
Tell him where you are from

extract_info.user_country: Extract the user's country from their message

user_goal.title: Answer his question about the Dutch language
user_goal.prompt: Ah, {user_country}! Interessant. Spreekt u al een beetje Nederlands?

user_goal.title: Say goodbye
user_goal.prompt: Dat is goed om te horen. Nou, een fijne dag verder!

content.text: Welkom bij Les 2! Today we'll learn to talk about our family, home, and how to share contact information.

data.tip: The Dutch 'r' is often rolled or tapped with the tongue, especially in the middle or at the end of a word.

content.title: Possessive Adjectives
content.explanation: To show ownership (my, your, his), you use possessive adjectives. Let's learn the singular ones first.

content.title: My
content.explanation: Mijn

content.title: Your (informal)
content.explanation: Jouw / Je

content.title: Your (formal)
content.explanation: Uw

content.title: His
content.explanation: Zijn

content.title: Her
content.explanation: Haar

content.text: For example: 'Mijn broer' means 'My brother'. 'Haar zus' means 'Her sister'.
You can use 'Ik heb' to talk about your family. For example: 'Ik heb een broer en een zus.' (I have a brother and a sister).

content.title: Chatting about Family
content.setting: You're getting to know a new Dutch friend, Mark. He starts asking about your family.

user_goal.title: Tell Mark about your family
user_goal.prompt: Hoi! Ik ben Mark. Ik heb één zus. Heb jij broers of zussen?

user_goal.title: Tell him your father's name
user_goal.prompt: Leuk! En hoe heet jouw vader?

extract_info.father_name: Extract the user's father's name from the message

user_goal.title: Respond to his comment
user_goal.prompt: Oké, dus zijn naam is {father_name}. Wat een leuke naam!

content.title: Numbers 0–10
content.explanation: 0: nul, 1: een, 2: twee, 3: drie, 4: vier, 5: vijf, 6: zes, 7: zeven, 8: acht, 9: negen, 10: tien.

content.title: Numbers 11–20
content.explanation: 11: elf, 12: twaalf, 13: dertien, 14: veertien, 15: vijftien, 16: zestien, 17: zeventien, 18: achttien, 19: negentien, 20: twintig.

content.title: Articles: 'De' and 'Het' Review
content.explanation: Remember that all nouns use 'de' or 'het' for 'the'. 'Het' is for neuter nouns, 'de' is for masculine/feminine nouns. Plurals always use 'de'.

data.tip: The 'ui' sound is unique to Dutch. It sounds like the 'ou' in the English word 'house' but with more rounded lips.

content.text: You can use this for cities or countries. Example: 'Ik woon in Amsterdam.'

content.title: Plurals: adding -en
content.explanation: A very common way to make a noun plural is to add '-en'. For example, 'de straat' (the street) becomes 'de straten' (the streets).

content.title: Plurals: adding -s
content.explanation: Another common way to form a plural is by adding '-s'. For example, 'de kamer' (the room) becomes 'de kamers' (the rooms).

content.title: Possessive Adjectives (Plural)
content.explanation: Now for the plural forms of 'our', 'your', and 'their'.

content.title: Our
content.explanation: Ons / Onze. Use 'ons' for 'het' words (ons huis) and 'onze' for 'de' words (onze familie).

content.title: Your (plural)
content.explanation: Jullie. Used when speaking to more than one person. Example: 'Jullie huis is groot.'

content.title: Their
content.explanation: Hun. Example: 'Hun ouders wonen in Utrecht.'

content.title: Numbers: The Tens
content.explanation: 20: twintig, 30: dertig, 40: veertig, 50: vijftig, 60: zestig, 70: zeventig, 80: tachtig, 90: negentig, 100: honderd.

content.title: Numbers: 21-99
content.explanation: Dutch numbers are read from right to left. 21 is 'eenentwintig' (one-and-twenty). 45 is 'vijfenveertig' (five-and-forty).

content.title: Getting a Library Card
content.setting: You are at the local library ('de bibliotheek') to get a membership card. The librarian asks for your contact information. Remember to be formal ('u'/'uw').

user_goal.title: Give the librarian your street and house number
user_goal.prompt: Goedemiddag. Ik help u graag. Wat is uw adres?

extract_info.user_street: Extract the user's street name from the message
extract_info.user_housenumber: Extract the user's house number from the message

user_goal.title: Tell them which city you live in
user_goal.prompt: Dank u. De {user_street} nummer {user_housenumber}. En in welke stad woont u?

extract_info.user_city: Extract the user's city from their message

user_goal.title: Provide your phone number
user_goal.prompt: Prima, {user_city}. En wat is uw telefoonnummer, alstublieft?

user_goal.title: Say thank you
user_goal.prompt: Perfect. Uw bibliotheekpas is klaar. Alstublieft.
